channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Gripped by dinosaurs, and a unified theory of behaviour: Books in Brief

Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00204-7

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Gripped by dinosaurs, and a unified theory of behaviour: Books in Brief

item.title: Unethical studies on Chinese minority groups are being retracted — but not fast enough, critics say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00170-0

Campaigners who want scrutiny of biometrics research on Uyghurs, Tibetans and other groups are frustrated by slow progress.
item.dc:title: Unethical studies on Chinese minority groups are being retracted — but not fast enough, critics say
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00187-5

Are we part of a unified work of absurd art?
item.dc:title: Are we part of a unified work of absurd art?
item.dc:creator: Ryan Shirlow

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: AlphaFold predicts thousands of possible psychedelics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00206-5

For the first time, predicted protein structures have been shown to be just as useful for drug discovery as experimentally derived ones. Plus, a plant-inspired robot that grows like a vine and how an AI figured out geometry.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: AlphaFold predicts thousands of possible psychedelics
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Can autoimmune diseases be cured? Scientists see hope at last
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00169-7

After decades of frustration and failed attempts, scientists might finally be on the cusp of developing therapies to restore immune ‘tolerance’ in conditions such as diabetes, lupus and multiple sclerosis.
item.dc:title: Can autoimmune diseases be cured? Scientists see hope at last
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: How does chronic stress harm the gut? New clues emerge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00188-4

A bacterium in the intestines of stressed mice interferes with cells that protect against pathogens.
item.dc:title: How does chronic stress harm the gut? New clues emerge
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: How Einstein built on the past to make his breakthroughs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00171-z

The iconic physicist’s theories of relativity and atomic motions were not so revolutionary, a penetrating history argues.
item.dc:title: How Einstein built on the past to make his breakthroughs
item.dc:creator: Helge Kragh

item.title: John L. Heilbron (1934–2023), historian of ‘big science’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00195-5

Rigorous historian who shed light on how researchers’ personalities and institutions are central to the development of scientific knowledge.
item.dc:title: John L. Heilbron (1934–2023), historian of ‘big science’
item.dc:creator: Cathryn Carson

item.title: Cities matter to the world’s future — science must serve them better
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00167-9

From governance to climate impacts, the world’s urban environments face many difficulties. A new journal, Nature Cities, aims to bring together researchers who are rising to the challenge.
item.dc:title: Cities matter to the world’s future — science must serve them better

item.title: Coping with climate change could be a matter of what building you’re in
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03934-2

Extreme heat and cold brought on by climate change put people at risk. Beefing up building codes now could help to save lives.
item.dc:title: Coping with climate change could be a matter of what building you’re in
item.dc:creator: Meredydd Evans

item.title: All arabica coffee is genetically similar: how can beans taste so different?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00165-x

Flavour variations are mainly the result of changes at the chromosome level, sequencing effort finds.
item.dc:title: All arabica coffee is genetically similar: how can beans taste so different?
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Two-faced AI language models learn to hide deception
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00189-3

‘Sleeper agents’ seem benign during testing but behave differently once deployed. And methods to stop them aren’t working.
item.dc:title: Two-faced AI language models learn to hide deception
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: Computers make mistakes and AI will make things worse — the law must recognize that
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00168-8

A tragic scandal at the UK Post Office highlights the need for legal change, especially as organizations embrace artificial intelligence to enhance decision-making.
item.dc:title: Computers make mistakes and AI will make things worse — the law must recognize that

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00173-x

item.dc:title: Seven technologies to watch in 2024
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: To curb plastic pollution, industry and academia must unite
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00155-z

Collaboration is key to making plastic use greener as soon as possible. Our experience yields tips on how to set up industry–academic partnerships.
item.dc:title: To curb plastic pollution, industry and academia must unite
item.dc:creator: Collin P. Ward
Christopher M. Reddy
Brian Edwards
Steven T. Perri

item.title: Daily briefing: Japanese spacecraft makes a pin-point landing on the Moon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00193-7

Japan has become the fifth country to land a lunar spacecraft. Plus, Nature’s pick of the technologies to get excited about and how to go further with open science.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Japanese spacecraft makes a pin-point landing on the Moon
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: The open-science movement for sharing laboratory materials gains momentum
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00172-y

Many researchers support open science, but how can they translate this view into behaviours to boost sharing?
item.dc:title: The open-science movement for sharing laboratory materials gains momentum
item.dc:creator: Andy Tay

item.title: Japan’s successful Moon landing was the most precise ever
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00151-3

Landing within 100 metres of its target zone, the craft has pioneered a new image-based automatic navigation system. But its mission might be cut short.
item.dc:title: Japan’s successful Moon landing was the most precise ever
item.dc:creator: Ling Xin

item.title: Pioneering nuclear-fusion reactor shuts down: what scientists will learn
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00135-3

The decommissioning of the Joint European Torus near Oxford, UK — a test bed for ITER — will take until 2040 and be studied in detail.
item.dc:title: Pioneering nuclear-fusion reactor shuts down: what scientists will learn
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00127-3

Next-generation plants that respond to demand could be key to making a low-carbon energy source more economically appealing.
item.dc:title: Flexible geothermal power makes it easier to harness Earth’s inner heat

item.title: Science’s fake-paper problem: high-profile effort will tackle paper mills
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00159-9

EXCLUSIVE: Poor-quality studies are polluting the literature — a group will study the businesses that produce them to stem the flow of bogus research.
item.dc:title: Science’s fake-paper problem: high-profile effort will tackle paper mills
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘I never felt I was going to work’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00182-w

Remembering life at Bell Labs’ ‘factory of ideas’ as it moves home. Plus, AlphaFold can find potential new psychedelics and biomarkers predict the risk of long COVID.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘I never felt I was going to work’
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Medical AI could be ‘dangerous’ for poorer nations, WHO warns
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00161-1

The rapid growth of generative AI in health care has prompted the agency to set out guidelines for ethical use.
item.dc:title: Medical AI could be ‘dangerous’ for poorer nations, WHO warns
item.dc:creator: David Adam

item.title: AlphaFold found thousands of possible psychedelics. Will its predictions help drug discovery?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00130-8

Researchers have doubted how useful the AI protein-structure tool will be in discovering medicines — now they are learning how to deploy it effectively.
item.dc:title: AlphaFold found thousands of possible psychedelics. Will its predictions help drug discovery?
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Fingertip oxygen sensors can fail on dark skin — now a physician is suing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00089-6

A community health centre in California led by the researcher files the first lawsuit against pulse oximeter manufacturers.
item.dc:title: Fingertip oxygen sensors can fail on dark skin — now a physician is suing
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: Long-COVID signatures identified in huge analysis of blood proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00158-w

Proteins involved in immunity, clotting and inflammation could help to unravel the complexity of long COVID.
item.dc:title: Long-COVID signatures identified in huge analysis of blood proteins
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Daily briefing: Cheap new pill provides potent COVID relief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00163-z

A drug called simnotrelvir speeds up recovery from mild to moderate COVID-19. Plus, an algorithm that is as good at geometry as maths-Olympiad gold medallists and new evidence challenges claim that the Black Death shaped the human genome.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Cheap new pill provides potent COVID relief
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: This AI just figured out geometry — is this a step towards artificial reasoning?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00145-1

How ‘AlphaGeometry’ solves Mathematical Olympiad-level problems, and what happens to an ecosystem after a mass predator die-off.
item.dc:title: This AI just figured out geometry — is this a step towards artificial reasoning?

item.title: Affinity-optimizing enhancer variants disrupt development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06922-8

Low-affinity transcription factor binding sites are prevalent across the genome, and single nucleotide changes that increase binding affinity even slightly can cause gain-of-function gene expression and phenotypes (such as polydactyly).
item.dc:title: Affinity-optimizing enhancer variants disrupt development
item.dc:creator: Fabian Lim
Joe J. Solvason
Genevieve E. Ryan
Sophia H. Le
Granton A. Jindal
Paige Steffen
Simran K. Jandu
Emma K. Farley

item.title: Multifunctional ytterbium oxide buffer for perovskite solar cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06892-x

Ytterbium oxide buffer layer for use in perovskite solar cells yields a certified power conversion efficiency of more than 25%, which enhances stability across a wide variety of perovskite compositions.
item.dc:title: Multifunctional ytterbium oxide buffer for perovskite solar cells
item.dc:creator: Peng Chen
Yun Xiao

item.title: Alternative splicing of latrophilin-3 controls synapse formation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06913-9

Latrophilin-3 organizes synapses through a convergent dual-pathway mechanism in which Gαs signalling is activated and phase-separated postsynaptic protein scaffolds are recruited.
item.dc:title: Alternative splicing of latrophilin-3 controls synapse formation
item.dc:creator: Shuai Wang
Chelsea DeLeon
Wenfei Sun
Stephen R. Quake
Bryan L. Roth
Thomas C. Südhof

item.title: Tuning commensurability in twisted van der Waals bilayers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06904-w

Using valley-resolved scanning tunnelling spectroscopy, twisted WSe2 bilayers are studied, including incommensurate dodecagon quasicrystals at 30° and commensurate moiré crystals at 21.8° and 38.2°.
item.dc:title: Tuning commensurability in twisted van der Waals bilayers
item.dc:creator: Yanxing Li
Fan Zhang
Viet-Anh Ha
Yu-Chuan Lin

item.title: Autoreactive T cells target peripheral nerves in Guillain–Barré syndrome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06916-6

Autoreactive T cells that target myelin antigens in the peripheral nerves are present in patients with the demyelinating form of Guillain–Barré syndrome, and these T cells are likely to contribute to disease pathophysiology.
item.dc:title: Autoreactive T cells target peripheral nerves in Guillain–Barré syndrome
item.dc:creator: L. Súkeníková
A. Mallone
B. Schreiner
P. Ripellino
J. Nilsson
M. Stoffel
S. E. Ulbrich
F. Sallusto
D. Latorre

item.title: Pattern recognition in the nucleation kinetics of non-equilibrium self-assembly
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06890-z

Examination of nucleation during self-assembly of multicomponent structures illustrates how ubiquitous molecular phenomena inherently classify high-dimensional patterns of concentrations in a manner similar to neural network computation.
item.dc:title: Pattern recognition in the nucleation kinetics of non-equilibrium self-assembly
item.dc:creator: Constantine Glen Evans
Jackson O’Brien
Erik Winfree
Arvind Murugan

item.title: Solving olympiad geometry without human demonstrations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06747-5

A new neuro-symbolic theorem prover for Euclidean plane geometry trained from scratch on millions of synthesized theorems and proofs outperforms the previous best method and reaches the performance of an olympiad gold medallist.
item.dc:title: Solving olympiad geometry without human demonstrations
item.dc:creator: Trieu H. Trinh
Yuhuai Wu
Quoc V. Le
He He
Thang Luong

item.title: Top-down control of flight by a non-canonical cortico-amygdala pathway
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06912-w

This study describes a projection from the medial prefrontal cortex to the central amygdala that is involved in the regulation of defensive responses to threat.
item.dc:title: Top-down control of flight by a non-canonical cortico-amygdala pathway
item.dc:creator: Chandrashekhar D. Borkar
Claire E. Stelly
Xin Fu
Maria Dorofeikova

Anh Duong
Erin Bean

Jonathan P. Fadok

item.title: Ubiquitous acceleration in Greenland Ice Sheet calving from 1985 to 2022
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06863-2

Analysis of more than 236,000 observations of glacier terminus positions shows that accelerated calving reduced the ice area of Greenland by about 5,000 km2 since 1985, producing over 1,000 Gt of freshwater that could influence ocean salinity and circulation.
item.dc:title: Ubiquitous acceleration in Greenland Ice Sheet calving from 1985 to 2022
item.dc:creator: Chad A. Greene
Alex S. Gardner
Michael Wood
Joshua K. Cuzzone

item.title: Predator mass mortality events restructure food webs through trophic decoupling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06931-7

Predator mass-mortality events lead to the proliferation of diverse consumer and producer communities resulting from weakened top-down predator control and stronger bottom-up effects through predator decomposition.
item.dc:title: Predator mass mortality events restructure food webs through trophic decoupling
item.dc:creator: Simon P. Tye
Samuel B. Fey
Jean P. Gibert
Adam M. Siepielski

item.title: Two-dimensional heavy fermions in the van der Waals metal CeSiI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06868-x

We present comprehensive thermodynamic and spectroscopic evidence for an antiferromagnetically ordered heavy-fermion ground state in the van der Waals metal CeSiI.
item.dc:title: Two-dimensional heavy fermions in the van der Waals metal CeSiI
item.dc:creator: Victoria A. Posey

item.title: Observation of interband Berry phase in laser-driven crystals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06828-5

The Berry phase is resolved in light-driven crystals, via attosecond interferometry, in which the electronic wavefunction accumulates a geometric phase as it interacts with the laser field, mapping its coherence into the emission of high-order harmonics.
item.dc:title: Observation of interband Berry phase in laser-driven crystals
item.dc:creator: Ayelet J. Uzan-Narovlansky
Lior Faeyrman

Nirit Dudovich

item.title: Stream–disk shocks as the origins of peak light in tidal disruption events
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06875-y

A three-dimensional radiation-hydrodynamic simulation of a tidal disruption event (TDE) flare from disruption to peak emission shows how deterministic predictions of TDE light curves and spectra can be calculated using moving-mesh hydrodynamics algorithms.
item.dc:title: Stream–disk shocks as the origins of peak light in tidal disruption events
item.dc:creator: Elad Steinberg
Nicholas C. Stone

item.title: A crime-busting path to planetary science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00142-4

Andrew Lincowski was a police officer before undertaking a PhD in astronomy and astrobiology. For a while, his career spanned both roles, before he moved into teaching.
item.dc:title: A crime-busting path to planetary science
item.dc:creator: Anne Gulland

item.title: The Alcubierre key
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00095-8

Mission improbable.
item.dc:title: The Alcubierre key
item.dc:creator: Jessica Brook

item.title: Could giant underwater curtains slow ice-sheet melting?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00119-3

The curtains would separate polar ice sheets from warm ocean waters — but like other geoengineering proposals, the idea divides scientists.
item.dc:title: Could giant underwater curtains slow ice-sheet melting?
item.dc:creator: Xiaoying You

item.title: The consciousness wars: can scientists ever agree on how the mind works?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00107-7

There are dozens of theories of how the brain produces conscious experience, and a new type of study is testing some of them head-to-head.
item.dc:title: The consciousness wars: can scientists ever agree on how the mind works?
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Predator die-off reshapes ecosystems in expected and unexpected ways
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04117-9

Mass-mortality events of predators are becoming more common, but their precise effects on food webs remain unclear. Experimentally induced predator die-offs led both to reduced predation and to fertilization from the bottom up. Together, these effects stabilized food webs.
item.dc:title: Predator die-off reshapes ecosystems in expected and unexpected ways

item.title: Greenland’s glaciers are retreating everywhere and all at once
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04108-w

A comprehensive analysis of satellite data finds that the Greenland ice sheet has lost more ice in the past four decades than previously thought. Moreover, the glaciers that are the most sensitive to seasonal temperature swings will probably retreat the most in response to future global warming.
item.dc:title: Greenland’s glaciers are retreating everywhere and all at once

item.title: Self-assembling DNA recognizes patterns
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03997-1

Self-assembling DNA can process information, but the computations have been limited to digital algorithms. A self-assembling DNA system has now been designed to perform complex pattern recognition.
item.dc:title: Self-assembling DNA recognizes patterns
item.dc:creator: Andrew Phillips

item.title: Potent new pill provides COVID relief for the masses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00117-5

The drug simnotrelvir shortens symptoms for those with mild infections and is sold at a lower price in China than its main rival.
item.dc:title: Potent new pill provides COVID relief for the masses
item.dc:creator: Saima Sidik

item.title: US particle physicists want to build a muon collider — Europe should pitch in
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00105-9

A feasibility study for a muon smasher in the United States could be an affordable way to maintain particle physics unity.
item.dc:title: US particle physicists want to build a muon collider — Europe should pitch in

item.title: Piracy at sea is waning — but hotspots remain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00124-6

A greater understanding of pirate attacks can help to inform the development of countermeasures.
item.dc:title: Piracy at sea is waning — but hotspots remain
item.dc:creator: Freda Kreier

item.title: Daily briefing: Can scientists ever agree on how consciousness works?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00153-1

Projects to test competing theories of consciousness are raising hopes that we’re making progress on one of science’s most intractable questions. Plus, a cloned rhesus monkey lives to adulthood for first time and what a 92-year-old elite athlete teaches us about healthy ageing.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Can scientists ever agree on how consciousness works?
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: A layered metal confines heavy electrons to two dimensions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04111-1

In heavy-fermion compounds, hybridization between mobile charge carriers and localized magnetic moments gives rise to exotic quantum phenomena. The discovery of heavy fermions in a van der Waals metal that can be peeled apart to a layer a few atoms thick allows these phenomena to be studied and manipulated in two dimensions.
item.dc:title: A layered metal confines heavy electrons to two dimensions

item.title: DeepMind AI solves geometry problems at star-student level
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00141-5

Algorithms are now as good at geometry as some of the world’s most mathematically talented school kids.
item.dc:title: DeepMind AI solves geometry problems at star-student level
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Large language models help computer programs to evolve
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03998-0

A branch of computer science known as genetic programming has been given a boost with the application of large language models that are trained on the combined intuition of the world’s programmers.
item.dc:title: Large language models help computer programs to evolve
item.dc:creator: Jean-Baptiste Mouret

item.title: Did the Black Death shape the human genome? Study challenges bold claim
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00137-1

An ancient-DNA study of medieval Cambridge found no sign of genes that helped people to survive the plague, casting doubt on an earlier study.
item.dc:title: Did the Black Death shape the human genome? Study challenges bold claim
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Scientists fear tough UK immigration rules will deter talent
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00123-7

Cost increases and restrictions on visa-holders bringing family members will put off researchers, warn scientists.
item.dc:title: Scientists fear tough UK immigration rules will deter talent
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson
